Based on the search results, here's what I found about FaceIQ analysis metrics breakdown on looksmax.org:

## FaceIQ Analysis Metrics

FaceIQ scores faces using a formula that evaluates facial harmony, angularity (leanness), dimorphism, and miscellaneous features.

### The Four Main Categories (HARM, DIMO, ANGU, MISC)

According to a detailed guide on looksmax.org that credits FaceIQ among other raters, the overall facial score uses these weighted percentages:
- **Harmony (HARM)**: 32%
- **Miscellaneous (MISC)**: 26%
- **Angularity (ANGU)**: 22%
- **Dimorphism (DIMO)**: 20%

### Alternative Weighting System

Some users believe faces should be rated using a different metric:
- Harmony: 40%
- Dimorphism: 20%
- Features: 25%
- Angularity: 15%

### Example Calculation

An example calculation works as follows:
- Harmony: 6.499 × 0.32 = 2.07968
- MISC: 6.916 × 0.26 = 1.79716
- ANGU: 3.973 × 0.22 = 0.87406
- DIMO: 7.92 × 0.20 = 1.58400

The weighted average (W) equals 6.33490.

### FaceIQ Labs Specific Measurements

FaceIQ Labs provides specific measurements including submental angle analysis. One user noted their submental was deemed "a major flaw" - the angle from submental connecting to neck.(no content)One user shared their FaceIQ Labs harmony score was 5.43/10, with dimorphism at 4.75, features at 4.5, and angularity at 5 (when debloated).

Based on my search results, here's what I found about FaceIQ scoring systems and percentile rankings for facial metrics:

There appear to be multiple services/products using the "FaceIQ" name:

## FaceIQ Labs (faceiqlabs.com)
This service provides detailed insights into every aspect of facial harmony, including overall, front, and side profile scores with percentile rankings.

## FaceIQ Rating Service (Gumroad)
This is a paid facial analysis service that provides a score out of 10 and your percentile of attractiveness based on an estimated distribution (for example, "Top 1% Looks").(no content)The FaceIQ YouTube channel/service scores faces using a formula that evaluates facial harmony, angularity (leanness), dimorphism, and miscellaneous features.

### Premium Analysis Option
The premium tier is described as "the ultimate facial report" for those "exceptionally interested in every aspect of their face." It includes a score out of 10, percentile of attractiveness, a description of the rating, best and worst features analysis, and custom morphs showing potential after changes.(no content)The full facial analysis includes 47 measurements, facial harmony front and side profile scores, and percentile rankings.

## FaceIQ App (Google Play)
There's also an AI-powered mobile app called FaceIQ that analyzes photos or selfies to provide personalized recommendations and scores.

## FaceIQ.io (Different Service)
This is a separate AI-powered facial analysis service focused on cosmetic procedures, providing comprehensive analysis of facial structure, symmetry, and unique features using advanced computer vision, with personalized suggestions for aesthetic treatments.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about FaceIQ results and how they're discussed on the Looksmax forum:

## FaceIQ Rating System Overview

FaceIQ is a YouTube-based rater who scores people on a formula that evaluates facial harmony, angularity (leanness), dimorphism, and miscellaneous features.

### The Rating Scale

According to FaceIQ's system, a 6/10 rating corresponds to the top 20% of faces.(no content)A score of 4/10 is considered bottom 25%, which indicates an average base.(no content)The median face rating is thought to be around 4.75.

### Scoring Categories

FaceIQ's system involves calculating multiple scores including: harmony score (HARM), dimorphism score (DIMO), angularity score (ANGU), and miscellaneous score (MISC), which are then combined into an objective looks rating.

### Cost and Services

A basic rating from FaceIQ costs $10.(no content)There's also a FaceIQ Labs service that costs $25/month, which provides more detailed analysis.

### Forum Opinions on Accuracy

Forum members have mixed opinions on FaceIQ's accuracy. The ratings are considered "sometimes good sometimes bad" - they work well when viewed through the "PSL standard" but may be less accurate elsewhere.(no content)Some forum members suggest subtracting 1.5 points from a FaceIQ rating to get the "actual value."(no content)One user who tested FaceIQ Labs found it "fairly accurate" but recommended running 3-4 tests and counting out outliers, as their scores ranged between 6.05/10 (top ~19%) and 6.29/10 (top ~14%).

### Tips for Using FaceIQ Labs

Users advise not using 2x zoom when taking photos for the rating, as this can cause inaccurate results (one user received a 4/10 when using zoom versus their usual 6+ rating).

content.content:
# FaceIQ Facial Metrics and Scoring System

## Scoring Components

FaceIQ rates faces using a formula evaluating four primary dimensions:
- **Facial harmony** - proportional balance of facial features
- **Angularity (leanness)** - definition and lack of bloating
- **Dimorphism** - masculine/feminine characteristics
- **Miscellaneous features** - additional aesthetic qualities

## Rating Scale & Classification

The system uses a 0-10 scale with percentile-based classifications:
- **4/10**: Bottom 25% (below average base)
- **4.75**: Estimated median face rating
- **5-5.5/10**: Top 25% (average to slightly above average)

## Identified Facial Flaws

The thread documents specific structural issues:

**Philtrum Issues:**
- Chin-to-philtrum ratio of 1.75 classified as "pretty big flaw"
- Philtrum-to-eye-orbit ratio of 0.67 (male model range: 0.325-0.4)
- Long midface ratio: 0.92

**Additional Flaws:**
- Upper eyelid excess (UEE)
- Facial recession (maxillary/mandibular)
- Thin upper lip
- Overall lack of angularity from body fat

## Improvement Projections

Weight loss from 25% to 15% body fat estimated to increase angularity score by 4 points, potentially raising overall rating by 1.5 points.

**Note:** No official FaceIQ documentation was provided; details derive from user experience narrative only.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about FaceIQ Labs and facial harmony side profile measurements, including information about the submental angle:

## FaceIQ Labs Overview

FaceIQ Labs offers 60+ precise facial measurements and a personalized action plan to improve your harmony score.(no content)Their adaptive scoring engine benchmarks every ratio against idealized datasets by ethnicity, gender, and age cohort, weighted for clinical significance.

### How It Works

Users upload front and side profile photos, and the system automatically standardizes images to the Frankfort plane for accurate measurements.(no content)Users receive a harmony score, 60+ facial ratios, and detailed insights including overall, front, and side profile scores with percentile rankings.

### Submental Angle Measurements

The submental angle is one of the measurements analyzed in the side profile. One user reported that their "submental was deemed as a major flaw" by FaceIQ Labs, specifically referring to "the angle from submental connecting to neck."(no content)The user noted that "photoshopping the submental differently makes no tangible impact on improving my looks although for a fatcel with a naturally small mandible, perhaps that submental angle would destroy them."

### Context on Submental Area in Side Profile

A double chin, also known as "submental fullness," can significantly compromise the aesthetics of the side profile. The excess fat accumulation beneath the jawline disrupts the smooth transition from chin to neck, creating an unflattering "bulge."

### Important Disclaimer

FaceIQ Labs is provided for entertainment and informational purposes only. Their facial analysis is not medical advice and should not be taken seriously or used for medical decisions.

content.content:
# FaceIQ Labs Facial Metrics Summary

## Harmony Scoring System
The platform uses an "adaptive scoring engine" that "benchmarks every ratio against idealized datasets by ethnicity, gender, and age cohort, weighted for clinical significance."

## Score Components
- **Overall Score**: 0-10 scale with percentile rankings (example: 7.42 = Top 12%)
- **Front Profile Score**: Separate measurement (example: 7.85 = Top 8%)
- **Side Profile Score**: Distinct evaluation (example: 6.98 = Top 18%)

## 60+ Facial Ratios Measured
Specific examples mentioned:
- Facial Thirds Ratio (8.2/10)
- Eye Spacing Ratio (7.8/10)
- Jaw Angle (6.5/10)
- Nasal Projection (7.1/10)

## Improvement Metrics
The platform projects potential improvements using a timeline format:
- Baseline score measurement
- Projected score with estimated gain (+1.43 example)
- Realistic maximum potential
- Top 1% potential score

## Classification Levels
Strengths/weaknesses categorized as: Ideal, Excellent, Moderate, and Minor (with severity percentages like -3.2%, -1.8%).

The page does not specify ideal values broken down by individual ethnicity/gender/age cohorts, though it mentions these groupings are used internally.

content.content:
# Facial Harmony Ratios Guide - Complete Extract

## Overview
The guide comprises **46 ratios and angles** distributed across **500 total points**:
- **Front Profile: 307 points (61%)**
- **Side Profile: 193 points (39%)**

Point allocation indicates relative importance—higher values = more critical features.

---

## FRONT PROFILE RATIOS

| Ratio | Ideal Range | Points |
|-------|-------------|--------|
| Nasal height to width | 0.62–0.88 | +5 |
| Bigonial/Bizygomatic width | 88–100% | +15 |
| Chin to philtrum | 2–2.5 | +12.5 |
| Bitemporal width | 89–100% | +5 |
| Total face height/width | 1.3–1.4 | +15 |
| FWHR (facial width-to-height) | 1.9–2.06 | +25 |
| Cheekbone high setedness | 81–100% | +25 |
| Mouth to nose width | 1.4–1.6 | +10 |
| **Upper facial third** | 33% | +30 |
| **Middle facial third** | 35% | (ideal) |
| **Lower facial third** | 33% | (ideal) |
| Lower third proportions | 0.33–0.4 | +5 |
| Lower to upper lip height | 0.33–0.4 | +7.5 |
| Midface ratio | 1.0 | +10 |
| Eye separation | 45–47% | +35 |
| Eye spacing | 0.93–1.04 | +10 |
| Canthal tilt | 5–7° | +30 |
| Eye aspect ratio/WHR | 3–3.7 | +10 |
| Eyebrow tilt | 5–13° | +5 |
| Eyebrow low-setedness | <0.5 | +10 |
| Orbital vector | Positive | +7.5 |
| Jaw frontal angle | 82–94° | +25 |
| Ipsilateral alar angle | 84–95° | +2.5 |
| Alar deviation from jaw angle | −2.5 to +2.5° | +7 |

---

## SIDE PROFILE RATIOS

| Ratio | Ideal Range | Points |
|-------|-------------|--------|
| Nasofrontal angle | 106–130° | +15 |
| Browridge inclination | 12–23° | +4 |
| Nasal tip angle | 103–113° | +4 |
| Nasolabial angle | 90–98.5° | +7.5 |
| Facial convexity (glabella) | 168–176° | +10 |
| Facial convexity (nasion) | 167–175° | +5 |
| Total facial convexity | 137–147° | +7.5 |
| Nasal projection | 0.5–0.7 | +5 |
| Nasomental angle | 125–132° | +5 |
| Nasofacial angle | 30–37° | +9 |
| **Gonial angle** | 113–125° | **+40** |
| Mandibular plane angle | 15–24° | +12.5 |
| Ramus to mandible ratio | 0–0.7 | +10 |
| Mentolabial angle | 108–117° | +7.5 |
| Recession (Frankfurt plane) | None | +5 |
| Gonion to mouth line | Below mouth | +6 |
| Rickets E-line | Upper lip 4mm behind lower | +5 |
| Holdaway H-line | Chin to upper lip | +5 |
| Steiner S-line | Chin, lower/upper lip | +5 |
| Burstone line | Pogonion to subnasale | +5 |
| Submental cervical angle | 92–100° | +10 |
| Neck to jaw width | 90–100% | +10 |

---

## Key Notes

**Severity Classification:** The guide notes that deviations of ±0.1 from FWHR incur approximately −5 points. Deviations well below/above the 1.8–2.1 range reduce harmony by approximately −25 points (5% of total).

**Measurement Basis:** Standards derived from "top male models and actors" including Jon Erik Hexum, Sean O'Pry, David Gandy, and Matt Bomer.

**No explicit major vs. minor flaw classifications** are provided beyond point allocation.

content.content:
# Facial Analysis Rating System: Complete Breakdown

## Rating Scale (2-10)

The system categorizes attractiveness by rarity:

- **9.1-10**: "1 in 1.2 million to billions" - near-perfect facial structure
- **9**: "1 in 1.2 million" - striking attractiveness with few flaws
- **8.5**: "1 in 58,000" - exceptionally attractive
- **8**: "1 in 4,100" - surpassingly attractive
- **7-7.5**: "1 in 68-440" - considerably attractive
- **6.5**: "1 in 16" - noticeably attractive
- **6**: "1 in 5.4" - decently attractive
- **5.5**: "1 in 2.7" - moderately attractive
- **5**: "1 in 2" - ordinary appearance
- **4.5**: "1 in 2.16" - below average
- **4 and below**: Increasingly unattractive

## Four-Component Scoring System

**Weighting Distribution:**
- **HARM (Harmony)**: 32% - proportional balance of facial features
- **MISC (Miscellaneous)**: 26% - skin, eyes, coloring, lips, nose, ears
- **ANGU (Angularity)**: 22% - facial sharpness and definition
- **DIMO (Dimorphism)**: 20% - masculine characteristics

## MISC Formula Components

Seven categories evaluated across 8 tiers (Tier 1 = best):

1. **Skin** (max 160 points): clearness, hyperpigmentation, texture, scarring, wrinkles
2. **Eye Area** (231 points): eyelids, sclera, lashes, brows, circles, color
3. **Coloring** (135 points): skin tone, lip color, eye/hair/brow darkness
4. **Lower Third** (170 points): gonions, chin shape/width, mandible features
5. **Lips** (110 points): width, philtrum length, fullness, health
6. **Nose** (110 points): alar width, bulbosity, tip definition, flare
7. **Other** (115 points): ear positioning, facial symmetry

**Calculation**: ((Score + 460) / 1491) × 100

## ANGU Formula

Nine features measuring angular definition across 7 tiers:

- Mandible visibility (24.75 max points)
- Facial 3D-ness (18.75)
- Gonion sharpness (18.75)
- Facial depth (17.25)
- Mandible/ramus visibility (16.74)
- Ogee curve (15.75)
- Cheekbone visibility (15.11)
- Chin angularity (12.30)
- Lower-midface fat (10.43)

**Max score**: 149.83 | **Min**: 19.03

## DIMO Formula

Eleven masculinity indicators across 5 tiers:

- Eye depth (22.32 max)
- Brow ridge shape (13.44)
- Chin shape (12.72)
- Buccal fat size (11.70)
- Ramus length (11.53)
- Gonion outward growth (11.04)
- Upper third narrowing (9.00)
- Facial hair (7.80)
- Skin texture (7.20)
- Cheekbone size (6.91)
- Lip fullness (6.34)

**Max**: 120 | **Min**: -67.44

## HARM Formula

Twenty-five proportional measurements across 7 tiers:

Major factors include jaw width, eye-brow distance, brow ridge angle, facial thirds (1:1:1 ratio), nasofrontal angle (125-135°), neck width, FWHR (1.8-2.0), eye aspect ratio, gonial angle (~120°), ramus length, chin-philtrum ratio (~1:2), lateral canthal tilt, bizygomatic width (140-150mm), midface height (47-50mm).

**Max**: 389.74 | **Min**: -409.92

## Overall Score Calculation

1. Normalize each component to 0-100 scale using formula: ((Score - Min) / (Max - Min)) × 100
2. Apply weighted percentages to get preliminary score
3. Calculate spread between highest and lowest component
4. **Apply penalty**: Spread × 0.5 (accounts for facial balance/cohesion)
5. **Final Score** = Weighted average - Penalty

The penalty mechanism prevents high scores in isolated categories from inflating overall ratings when other areas are deficient.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about FaceIQ free vs paid version comparisons:

## FaceIQ Products and Versions

There appear to be multiple FaceIQ-related services:

### FaceIQ Rating (Basic/Free Tier)
If you are looking for an accurate, honest, and informed analysis of your attractiveness, you can receive a score /10, your percentile of attractiveness based on an estimated distribution (e.g., Top 1% Looks), and a description of your rating.(no content)This service has a 1-7 day delivery time and all facial analysis is 100% private and confidential.

### FaceIQ Premium Analysis (Paid Tier)
This is described as "the ultimate facial report" for those exceptionally interested in every aspect of their face. It includes a score /10, your percentile of attractiveness, a description of your rating, Best and Worst Features, ALL Softmaxing Advice, ALL Possible Hardmaxxes, Order of Operations (Complete step-by-step plan), Custom Morph Of Changes, and Estimated Score Of Your Potential After Changes.(no content)This version has a 7-28 day delivery time.

### FaceIQ Labs
FaceIQ Labs offers the ability to "discover your facial harmony with 60+ precise measurements" and "get objective insights into your attractiveness with our advanced facial analysis system."

### FaceIQ Mobile App
FaceIQ - AI Face Analyzer is FREE to download.(no content)The app offers a comprehensive range of tips and recommendations, from skincare routines to hairstyle choices, clothing styles, and accessory suggestions.(no content)You simply upload a photo or take a selfie, and FaceIQ will analyze your appearance, providing personalized recommendations that align with your unique features.

### Scoring Metrics
FaceIQ scores on a formula for facial harmony, angularity (leanness), dimorphism, and miscellaneous features.

## QOVES Facial Analysis Overview

QOVES is an advanced facial analysis company that leverages artificial intelligence to deliver AI-driven facial assessment, aesthetics consultation, and biometric analysis. Initially launched as a project focused on aesthetic facial harmonization, QOVES has evolved into a full-scale technology company.

### Key Metrics and Analysis Features

QOVES Studio's Facial Assessment Tool employs advanced AI algorithms to evaluate facial features using a database of 35,000+ images across races, ages, and genders. It measures 112 parameters such as symmetry, proportions, and skin health to generate actionable insights.(no content)The tool evaluates facial harmony through cephalometric measurements (e.g., nasofrontal angles, orbital tilt) backed by 30+ scientific studies for objective insights.

### Harmony and Scoring Approach

The AI calculates scores for attractiveness, facial harmony, and biometric matching.(no content)The analysis evaluates "how well the different parts of your face are sized and spaced in relation to each other" as part of their harmony assessment.

However, regarding traditional "beauty scores," QOVES is firmly against the idea of 'scoring' beauty on a 1-10 scale, stating it is "simply unproductive and does not actually have much commercial use either from a business point of view."(no content)Their ethical AI framework avoids generalized 'beauty scores' by focusing on individual deviations from population averages to reduce algorithmic bias.

### Percentile Rankings

Notably, a related service called FaceIQ Labs offers "detailed insights into every aspect of your facial harmony" with "overall, front, and side profile scores with percentile rankings." Some users have mentioned connections between FaceIQ and former QOVES personnel.

### What QOVES Reports Include

QOVES analysis provides your current scores and potential for improvement, detailed breakdowns on each facial feature, how your features work together, what you can improve without surgery, and scientific explanations for recommendations.

Based on the search results, here's a summary of the key information about canthal tilt, IPD (interpupillary distance), eye separation, and ideal facial ratios according to looksmaxxing communities:

## Key Eye Area Ratios and Ideal Measurements

### Eye Separation Ratio (ESR)
The ideal eye separation ratio is 44.3-47.4% of bizygomatic width.(no content)To calculate the ESR, you divide your IPD (interpupillary distance) by your bizygomatic width (the widest part of the face). The ideal range for the ES ratio is 0.45-0.47.(no content)If the ES ratio deviates from 0.46 by 0.02 or more, chances are the face will look unusual.(no content)A ratio below 0.45 isn't ideal, but it's not necessarily problematic as long as it's not less than 0.42. A ratio of 0.42 is considered the minimum required to be aesthetically acceptable.

### Eye Spacing
For intercanthal distance, eyes should be spaced roughly one eye apart, with 0.93-1.04 being a good range.

### Canthal Tilt
The ideal palpebral axis (canthal tilt) is 5.2-8.5 degrees positive.(no content)Canthal tilt of 4°-6° is measured by calculating the angle formed upon setting the vertex at the medial canthus with the arms set parallel to the floor and the lateral canthus.(no content)There are three types of canthal tilts: Positive (ideal) where the angle is smaller than 180 degrees, Neutral where the angle equals 180 degrees, and Negative where the angle is higher than 180 degrees.(no content)For men specifically, a canthal tilt of 5.2 to 7.6 degrees is considered good, with 8° being a good ratio.

### Eye Aspect Ratio
The ideal eye aspect ratio (width to height) is between 2.8-3.7.(no content)Eyes that are 3x1 wider than tall are considered extremely masculine, with the ideal range being between 2.8 to 3.5.

### IPD in Context
IPD as a ratio of face width ideally falls around 0.39-0.42.(no content)Eye position cannot be surgically changed, so the only way to modify the ES ratio is by augmenting or reducing cheekbones.

- "Your percentile of attractiveness (For example, Top 1% Looks)"

**Feature Analysis:**

Based on the search results, here's what I found about midface ratio, facial thirds, and ideal measurements from the "looksmax" community:

## Midface Ratio

The midface ratio is measured by dividing the interpupillary distance (distance between the centers of the pupils) by the height of the nasion to the upper lip. The closer to 1:1 this is, the better.(no content)The ideal midface ratio is considered to be around 1.0. However, there's some debate in the community:

- Some claim the ideal midface ratio is 0.95-1.05.

Based on the search results, here's an overview of looksmax surgery recommendations related to facial analysis, gonial angle, and jaw surgery:

## Gonial Angle and Jaw Surgery in Looksmaxxing

### What is the Gonial Angle?
The gonial angle, also known as the mandibular angle, is the angle formed by the lower border of the mandible (jawbone) and the posterior border of the ramus (the vertical portion of the lower jaw). This angle plays a significant role in determining the shape and definition of your jawline.(no content)The gonial angle is the angle of the lower jaw and plays a crucial role in jawline aesthetics. A well-defined gonial angle is more square and prominent, while a rounded angle can make the face look softer and less defined.

### Ideal Measurements
The gonial angle typically ranges from 120 to 130 degrees in adults.(no content)Some individuals seek to achieve a gonial angle closer to 90 degrees for a more defined appearance, either through natural methods like mewing and jaw exercises or through surgery.

### Surgical Options

**Gonial Angle Enhancement Surgery:**
The gonial angle can be surgically shaved or augmented to provide a more pronounced and squared jaw; this is usually performed along with mandibular angle augmentation. The benefit is a more powerful and chiseled jaw that amplifies facial masculinity or symmetry.

**BSSO (Bilateral Sagittal Split Osteotomy):**
This surgery can result in a decrease in lower third height or increase in lower third height but with an increase in gonial notch visibility. Counter-clockwise rotation will increase the upswing of the face. This jaw surgery is often paired with a LeFort 1, which is then called a bimax.

**Bimax Surgery:**
Bimax surgery with CCW rotation can involve significant movements - one patient reported 13° CCW rotation with nearly 30mm advancement in the lower jaw.(no content)If you have an overbite, a BSSO would help a lot. If you don't have an overbite, a specialized genioplasty, such as a mini wing genioplasty, would likely be sufficient. Wraparound jaw implants are another option, though osteotomies are often considered superior for the lower third.

### Important Considerations

The optimal gonial angle depends on ramus length - if you have a short ramus you'll look better with a high gonial angle, if you have a long ramus then a lower gonial angle may be preferable.(no content)Features need to work harmoniously together. You need to consider almost every ratio on your face - if even one ratio strays drastically from the population average, you may end up looking uncanny.(no content)"Dogmaxxing" is a term used for bimax patients whose lower midface seems to be too far forward, giving them an uncanny profile. This mostly happens in patients who do not get enough CCW rotation and only get normal advancement.

content.content:
# Facial Surgery Guide: Procedures and Aesthetic Improvements

## Surgery-to-Flaw Mapping

| Surgery | Addresses | Metric Improved |
|---------|-----------|-----------------|
| Platysmaplasty | Weak cervicomental angle | "sharper, well-defined angle" between chin/neck |
| Submental Liposuction | Submental fat deposits | Jawline definition and angle sharpness |
| Zygomatic Implants | Flat cheekbones | Cheekbone projection and facial width |
| Infraorbital Rim Implants | Sunken/hollow eyes | Under-eye support and youthful appearance |
| Fat Grafting (periorbital) | Lost volume under eyes | Permanent volume restoration vs. temporary fillers |
| Mandibular Implants | Weak jawline | "strong, masculine jawline" and lower third balance |
| Jaw Reduction | Overly wide/prominent jaw | Proportional jaw balance |
| Alar Base Reduction | Flared nostrils | Nostril width refinement |
| SARPE (Palate Expansion) | Narrow palate | Facial width and dental alignment |
| Gonial Angle Surgery | Rounded jaw angle | Square, defined jaw appearance |
| Temple Fillers | Temporal hollowing | Fuller upper face; youthful appearance |
| Lip Lift | Long philtrum/sagging corners | "lifted, more inviting appearance" around mouth |
| Lateral Canthopexy | Round eye shape | "almond-shaped, elongated eye" aesthetic |
| Brow Bone Contouring | Prominent/flat brow ridge | Balanced eye framing |
| Buccal Fat Removal | Round "baby face" | "slimmer, more contoured midface with sharper cheekbones" |
| Chin Wing Osteotomy | Weak chin and jawline | Comprehensive lower third definition |
| Trapezius Botox | Overdeveloped trapezius | Neck length and shoulder refinement |
| Facial Liposuction | Jowls and lower face fat | Jawline visibility and reduced sagging |
| LeFort I Osteotomy | Recessed midface | Cheekbone projection and smile aesthetics |
| Orbital Rim Surgery | Deep-set or prominent eyes | Eye symmetry and orbital balance |
| Lower Canthoplasty | Drooping lower eyelids | "fox-eye" or almond shape achievement |
| Sliding Genioplasty | Weak chin projection | Natural bone-based chin enhancement |
| Forehead Augmentation | Flat/sloped forehead | Proportionate facial framing |

## Notable Absence

The document **provides no specific measurement thresholds or ratio recommendations** for determining surgical candidacy. Procedures are described qualitatively rather than quantitatively.

FaceIQ Labs uses an adaptive scoring engine that benchmarks facial ratios against idealized datasets by ethnicity, gender, and age cohort, weighted for clinical significance.(no content)They provide facial analysis and a personalized action plan to maximize harmony scores.

### How It Works
The software relies on the user to plot points on their face, and then performs simple division calculations to determine facial harmony scores.

### Community Reception
The Looksmax community has mixed views on FaceIQ ratings:

Based on the search results, I found information about FaceIQ and the concepts of "hardmax" (or "hardmaxxing") and "softmax" (or "softmaxxing") in the context of facial attractiveness recommendations.

## FaceIQ Premium Analysis

FaceIQ offers what they describe as "the ultimate facial report" for those interested in every aspect of their face. The service provides:

- A score out of 10
- Your percentile of attractiveness (e.g., "Top 1% Looks")
- A description of your rating
- Best and worst features
- ALL Softmaxing Advice
- ALL Possible Hardmaxxes
- Order of Operations (a complete step-by-step plan)
- Custom morph of changes
- **Estimated Score of Your Potential After Changes**(no content)The service has a 7-28 day delivery time and claims to be 100% private and confidential.

## Softmaxxing vs. Hardmaxxing Definitions

**Softmaxxing** involves non-invasive practices ranging from common actions like moisturizing and getting a haircut, to more unique activities like "mewing" (tongue exercises to improve jaw structure). These activities are predominantly accessible and easily sustained, making them popular within the looksmaxxing community.(no content)**Hardmaxxing** refers to more permanent, costly, and sometimes risky methods, such as cosmetic surgery, bone smashing, and limb lengthening.(no content)According to one guide, softmaxxing consists of "non-invasive, reversible, low-risk improvements that increase attractiveness without surgery or medical intervention," and claims "this is where 50-70% of your looks potential comes from."

Based on my search, here's what I found about the PSL scale and its relationship to facial harmony, percentile distribution, and attractiveness:

## PSL Scale Overview

PSL stands for the amalgamation of three defunct forums: PUAHate, SlutHate, and Lookism.(no content)The PSL scale is a way to figure out how attractive someone is based solely on their face. The central idea behind PSL ratings is not purely finding one's SMV/appeal, but it can be better described as giving objective ratings based on Facial Harmony, Balance, Symmetry, Sexual Dimorphism, Unique qualities, and averageness.

## Normal Distribution Model

PSL Scale uses a normal distribution mindset where 4 PSL represents average, 5–6 PSL is above average to attractive, and 7+ PSL represents elite/model-level features.(no content)In this conceptualization of looks ratings, 4 PSL represents the median physical attractiveness for an individual of a certain sex, while 8 PSL means literal perfection. That means most people are near the median attractiveness (or the 50th percentile), 4 PSL, while a small minority of the population is 6 PSL or higher.(no content)It claims to measure attractiveness on a more normal distribution than the Decile chart commonly used by Normies to rate attractiveness, which is often claimed by proponents of the PSL scale to render inflated attractiveness ratings.

## Scale Range and Tiers

Because a facial rating of 10 or even 9 doesn't exist, the PSL scale only ranges up to 8, with 4 serving as the midpoint.

Key tiers include:
- 4 PSL is dead average. Most men will be within this area (3.5-4.5), and it is the most common that you will see. Nothing will stand out about their faces, and nothing is noticeably ugly or unappealing.
- A high tier normie (HTN) generally falls between 5 PSL to 6 PSL on this scale. High tier normies occupy this range, representing individuals who are considered attractive by most people but don't possess the exceptional features required for modeling or "Chad" status.
- The people in the 7+ rating will be considered some of the best looking people in the world. Near-perfect facial symmetry, unique features, top-tier bone structure, and incredible facial Harmony is common in this rating. Only the top models and the best looking Hollywood actors out there belong in this category.
- Those that are 7.5 PSL are the most attractive people of all time and 1 in a few billion. These people are usually where human facial aesthetics hit its full peak and in some candids these people look fake due to how developed, harmonic & how perfect their facial structure is.

## Facial Harmony Criteria

Looks are rated across four categories: "harmony," the cohesiveness of one's features; "dimorphism," how distinct you look from the opposite sex; "angularity," the keenness of one's features, which correlates to low body fat; and "miscellaneous features."(no content)The PSL system breaks down facial attractiveness into quantifiable metrics including: Harmony (alignment with the golden ratio 1.618:1, where features like eye spacing and jawline angles adhere to proportional ideals), Jawline Definition (a sharp, well-defined jawline with an angle >110° is considered optimal for masculinity), and Midface Ratio (balanced midface proportions signal genetic fitness).

## Scientific Basis

While PSL borrows concepts from aesthetic studies (e.g., the golden ratio, facial symmetry), it is not formally recognized in peer-reviewed research.

content.content:
# PSL Rating Scale Summary

## Overview
PSL ratings evaluate "facial attractiveness based on Facial Harmony, Balance, Symmetry, Sexual Dimorphism, Unique qualities, and averageness."

## Population Percentiles
- PSL 4 = 50th percentile
- PSL 5 = 84.15th percentile
- PSL 6 = 97.25th percentile
- PSL 7 = 99.87th percentile
- PSL 8 = 99.9968th percentile

## Rating Tiers

**Below 2 PSL**: Individuals considered "ugly by the entirety of the population." Faces display minimal harmony and poor features throughout.

**3 PSL**: "Noticeably below average" with lacking facial harmony, ratios, and features. Common asymmetry present.

**4 PSL**: Dead average range (3.5-4.5). Nothing remarkable about facial appearance—neither notably attractive nor unattractive.

**4.5 PSL**: Above average, found attractive by many. Decent individual features with acceptable ratios.

**5 PSL**: "Start getting appreciated for your looks." Good facial harmony with decent features; minor flaws may prevent higher ratings.

**5.5 PSL**: "Noticeably very good looking." Strong jawlines, soft features, and excellent collagen quality present.

**6 PSL**: Model tier begins here. Requires "great facial harmony" with sexually dimorphic, classically handsome features. One or two minor imperfections acceptable.

**6.5 PSL**: "Extremely attractive and well into model tier." No flaws; essentially all features rank top-tier.

**7 PSL**: Among world's best-looking individuals. Near-perfect symmetry, unique features, and superior bone structure required.

**7.5 PSL**: "Near perfect score." Virtually flawless facial features; extremely rare achievement.

**7.5+**: "Almost unheard of." Reserved for the most aesthetically perfect individuals in history.

Based on the search results, here's what the looksmax community discusses regarding the ideal bigonial width to bizygomatic width ratio:

## Ideal Bigonial to Bizygomatic Width Ratios

There are varying opinions on the ideal ratio between jaw width (bigonial) and cheekbone width (bizygomatic):

### The 1.35 Ratio (Bizygomatic/Bigonial)
"Bizygomatic to bigonial width: 1.35 measured by dividing the bizygomatic width (distance from cheekbone to cheekbone) by the bigonial width (distance from gonion to gonion)." This is one commonly cited "ideal" ratio.

### Alternative Ratios
Some guides suggest "Bigonial width/Bizygomatic width 88%-100%" as the ideal range for facial harmony.

Another perspective states that "Bigonial width should be 70-75% of bizygomatic width."(no content)"Most stars got an 90 to 95 bigonial to bizygo ratio, so slightly shorter" than a 1:1 ratio.

### The 1:1 Debate
There's significant disagreement about whether a 1:1 ratio is ideal:
- "I see this mentioned every once in a while, how a jaw as wide as cheekbones is ideal or very masculine or something. In reality however, 1:1 bigonial to bizygomatic is almost always shit for aesthetics."
- "A nice soft tapering from bizygomatic to bigonial is ideal. Jaw is not too narrow and you still have facial angularity."

### Key Considerations
"Bigonial width is the distance between the two gonions (the edges of the mandible where it meets the ramus). It determines how wide the lower jaw looks from the front. If your bigonial width is a lot lower than your interzygomatic width (distance between the cheekbones), your lower jaw will look too narrow."(no content)The ideal jaw "should be well developed and wide, though not too wide, slightly narrower than the bizygomatic width."

Based on my search results, here's what research and online communities say about the Facial Width-to-Height Ratio (FWHR):

## What is FWHR?
FWHR, or Facial Width-to-Height Ratio, is a measurement that compares the width of the face to its height. The ratio is calculated by dividing the bizygomatic width (the distance between the cheekbones) by the upper facial height (the distance from the upper lip to the midbrow).

## "Ideal" Measurements
There's no universally "ideal" FWHR, but research suggests that ratios between 1.75 and 2.0 are often perceived as attractive in males.(no content)Some online communities suggest an FWHR of 1.8+ as the ideal for men.

## Associations with Masculinity
High FWHR is linked to stronger, more masculine features, whereas lower ratios may be perceived as more feminine.(no content)Men with larger fWHRs (i.e., wider faces) are perceived as more masculine, socially dominant and physically aggressive, but not more attractive, than men with smaller fWHRs.

## Research Findings
Research has shown that higher FWHR is associated with various physical and behavioral traits, such as adolescent testosterone, aggression, attractiveness to women, cause of death by violence, CEO success as measured by organizational and financial performance, and success in sports.(no content)Men with relatively larger FWHRs are considered masculine, unattractive and physically formidable. As in previous research, these men were also considered likely to become aggressive if provoked.

## Caveats
Despite the considerable hype surrounding fWHR in circles concerned with aesthetics, there is a lack of evidence directly linking this trait to perceptions of greater male physical attractiveness.(no content)A re-analysis of previous studies after excluding skull samples found little evidence of sexual dimorphism in faces. Considering ethnicities separately, there were no differences for White samples. Researchers found no reason to consider FWHR as a sexually dimorphic measure in skulls or faces universally.(no content)While a high FWHR is often associated with masculinity, there's no universal standard for attractiveness. Cultural and individual preferences play a significant role, and factors like facial symmetry, skin quality, and expression also influence perceptions of beauty.

Based on my search results, here's what research and online communities say about the Facial Width-to-Height Ratio (FWHR):

## What is FWHR?
FWHR, or Facial Width-to-Height Ratio, is a measurement that compares the width of the face to its height. The ratio is calculated by dividing the bizygomatic width (the distance between the cheekbones) by the upper facial height (the distance from the upper lip to the midbrow).

## "Ideal" Measurements
There's no universally "ideal" FWHR, but research suggests that ratios between 1.75 and 2.0 are often perceived as attractive in males.(no content)Some online communities suggest an FWHR of 1.8+ as the ideal for men.

## Associations with Masculinity
High FWHR is linked to stronger, more masculine features, whereas lower ratios may be perceived as more feminine.(no content)Men with larger fWHRs (i.e., wider faces) are perceived as more masculine, socially dominant and physically aggressive, but not more attractive, than men with smaller fWHRs.

## Research Findings
Research has shown that higher FWHR is associated with various physical and behavioral traits, such as adolescent testosterone, aggression, attractiveness to women, cause of death by violence, CEO success as measured by organizational and financial performance, and success in sports.(no content)Men with relatively larger FWHRs are considered masculine, unattractive and physically formidable. As in previous research, these men were also considered likely to become aggressive if provoked.

## Caveats
Despite the considerable hype surrounding fWHR in circles concerned with aesthetics, there is a lack of evidence directly linking this trait to perceptions of greater male physical attractiveness.(no content)A re-analysis of previous studies after excluding skull samples found little evidence of sexual dimorphism in faces. Considering ethnicities separately, there were no differences for White samples. Researchers found no reason to consider FWHR as a sexually dimorphic measure in skulls or faces universally.(no content)While a high FWHR is often associated with masculinity, there's no universal standard for attractiveness. Cultural and individual preferences play a significant role, and factors like facial symmetry, skin quality, and expression also influence perceptions of beauty.

# Ideal Facial Ratios and Proportions

## Front Profile Measurements

**Facial Width to Height Ratio (FWHR): 1.8+**
Calculated by dividing bizygomatic width by the distance from eyebrow midpoint to upper lip.

**Lower/Full Face Ratio: 0.62+**
Divides nasion-to-chin height by total face height (hairline to chin).

**Midface Ratio: 1.0-1.1**
Interpupillary distance divided by nasion-to-upper lip height; closer to 1:1 is optimal.

**Mouth to Nose Ratio: 1.5-1.62**
Mouth width divided by nose width.

**Lower to Upper Lip Ratio: 1.62**
Lower lip height divided by upper lip height.

**Chin to Philtrum Ratio: 2.0-2.25**
Middle lip-to-chin height divided by nose-to-middle lip height.

**Bizygomatic to Bigonial Width: 1.35**
Cheekbone width divided by jaw width (gonion to gonion).

**Eye Separation Ratio (ESR): 0.45-0.47**
Interpupillary distance divided by bizygomatic width. The thread notes the "third eyeball" theory is flawed.

## Angle Measurements

**EME (Eye-Mouth-Eye) Angle: 47°-50°**
Vertex at lip center with arms crossing eye pupils; indicates masculinity and symmetry.

**Cervicomental Angle: 105°-120°**
Vertex at hyoid with arms along chin and neck; angles above 120° suggest double chin appearance.

**Gonial Angle: 115°-130°**
Vertex at gonion with arms along mandible and ramus.

**Canthal Tilt: 4°-6°**
Medial-to-lateral canthus angle relative to horizontal.

## Additional Proportions

**Palpebral Fissure Length to Height Ratio: 3.0-3.5**
Palpebral fissure length divided by upper and lower eyelid height combined.

**Forehead Height: 3 fingers**
Measured by counting clenched fingers horizontally before hairline.

**Facial Thirds: Equal divisions**
Upper, middle, and lower thirds should each represent approximately one-third of total face height.

**Facial Fifths: Equal divisions**
Nose width, palpebral fissure length, and lateral canthus-to-ear distance should each equal one-fifth of ear-to-ear width.

# FaceIQ and Looksmax Facial Metrics Research

## Overview

This document compiles research from Looksmax.org forums and related sources about FaceIQ analysis, facial metrics, ideal values, severity classifications, and surgery recommendations.

---

## FaceIQ Services Overview

### FaceIQ Products

| Service | Price | Features |
|---------|-------|----------|
| **FaceIQ Basic Rating** | $10 | Score /10, percentile, rating description |
| **FaceIQ Premium Analysis** | Paid | 47 measurements, softmax/hardmax advice, morphs, potential score |
| **FaceIQ Labs** | $25/month | 60+ measurements, front/side harmony scores, percentile rankings |

### FaceIQ Scoring Formula (4 Components)

FaceIQ rates faces using a weighted formula:

| Component | Weight | Description |
|-----------|--------|-------------|
| **HARM (Harmony)** | 32% | Proportional balance of facial features |
| **MISC (Miscellaneous)** | 26% | Skin, eyes, coloring, lips, nose, ears |
| **ANGU (Angularity)** | 22% | Facial sharpness and definition |
| **DIMO (Dimorphism)** | 20% | Masculine/feminine characteristics |

**Example Calculation:**
```
Harmony: 6.499 x 0.32 = 2.07968
MISC: 6.916 x 0.26 = 1.79716
ANGU: 3.973 x 0.22 = 0.87406
DIMO: 7.92 x 0.20 = 1.58400
Weighted Average = 6.33490
```

### FaceIQ Labs Score Components

- **Overall Score**: 0-10 with percentile (e.g., 7.42 = Top 12%)
- **Front Profile Score**: Separate measurement (e.g., 7.85 = Top 8%)
- **Side Profile Score**: Distinct evaluation (e.g., 6.98 = Top 18%)

### Severity Classification Levels (FaceIQ Labs)

| Classification | Meaning |
|----------------|---------|
| **Ideal** | Perfect/optimal range |
| **Excellent** | Near-ideal with minimal deviation |
| **Moderate** | Noticeable deviation (e.g., -1.8%) |
| **Minor** | Small flaw (e.g., -3.2%) |
| **Major Flaw** | Significant deviation requiring attention |

---

## PSL Rating Scale

The PSL (PUAHate/SlutHate/Lookism) scale uses a normal distribution model:

### Percentile Distribution

| PSL Score | Percentile | Description |
|-----------|------------|-------------|
| 2 | Bottom | Ugly by entirety of population |
| 3 | ~16% | Noticeably below average |
| 4 | 50% (median) | Dead average |
| 4.5 | ~66% | Above average |
| 5 | 84.15% | Start getting appreciated for looks |
| 5.5 | ~92% | Noticeably very good looking |
| 6 | 97.25% | Model tier begins |
| 6.5 | ~99% | Extremely attractive, model tier |
| 7 | 99.87% | Among world's best looking |
| 7.5 | 99.9968% | Near perfect, extremely rare |
| 8 | ~1 in billions | Theoretical perfection |

### PSL Tier Names

| Score Range | Tier Name |
|-------------|-----------|
| 2-3 | Subhuman |
| 3-4 | Below Average |
| 4-4.5 | Normie |
| 4.5-5 | High Tier Normie (HTN) |
| 5-5.5 | Chadlite |
| 6+ | Chad |
| 7+ | Gigachad |

---

## Complete Facial Metrics Reference

### FRONT PROFILE RATIOS (307 points / 61% weight)

| # | Ratio | Ideal Range | Points | Importance |
|---|-------|-------------|--------|------------|
| 1 | **FWHR (Facial Width-to-Height)** | 1.9-2.06 | 25 | Extremely Important |
| 2 | **Eye Separation Ratio (ESR)** | 44.3-47.4% | 35 | Really Important |
| 3 | **Eye Spacing (Intercanthal)** | 0.93-1.04 | 10 | Really Important |
| 4 | **Canthal Tilt (Palpebral Axis)** | 5-7 degrees | 30 | Extremely Important |
| 5 | **Eye Aspect Ratio (WHR)** | 2.8-3.7 | 10 | Really Important |
| 6 | **Facial Thirds** | 33%/35%/33% | 30 | Upper third weight |
| 7 | **Midface Ratio** | 0.93-1.01 | 10 | Really Important |
| 8 | **Cheekbone Position (High-setedness)** | 81-100% | 25 | Extremely Important |
| 9 | **Bigonial/Bizygomatic Width** | 88-100% | 15 | Really Important |
| 10 | **Bitemporal Width** | 89-100% | 5 | Really Important |
| 11 | **Total Face Height/Width** | 1.3-1.4 | 15 | Important |
| 12 | **Jaw Frontal Angle** | 82-94 degrees | 25 | Really Important |
| 13 | **Chin to Philtrum Ratio** | 2-2.55 | 12.5 | Really Important |
| 14 | **Mouth to Nose Width** | 1.4-1.6 | 10 | Really Important |
| 15 | **Lower to Upper Lip Height** | 0.33-0.4 | 7.5 | Important |
| 16 | **Nasal Height to Width** | 0.62-0.88 | 5 | Important |
| 17 | **Eyebrow Tilt** | 5-13 degrees | 5 | Important |
| 18 | **Eyebrow Low-setedness** | <0.5 | 10 | Important |
| 19 | **Orbital Vector** | Positive | 7.5 | Extremely Important |
| 20 | **Ipsilateral Alar Angle** | 84-95 degrees | 2.5 | Minor |
| 21 | **Alar Deviation from Jaw Angle** | +/-2.5 degrees | 7 | Minor |
| 22 | **Lower Third Proportions** | 0.33-0.4 | 5 | Extremely Important |

### SIDE PROFILE RATIOS (193 points / 39% weight)

| # | Ratio | Ideal Range | Points | Importance |
|---|-------|-------------|--------|------------|
| 1 | **Gonial Angle** | 113-125 degrees | 40 | Extremely Important |
| 2 | **Mandibular Plane Angle** | 15-24 degrees | 12.5 | Really Important |
| 3 | **Ramus to Mandible Ratio** | 0-0.7 | 10 | Really Important |
| 4 | **Nasofrontal Angle** | 106-130 degrees | 15 | Really Important |
| 5 | **Browridge Inclination** | 12-23 degrees | 4 | Important |
| 6 | **Nasal Tip Angle** | 103-113 degrees | 4 | Important |
| 7 | **Nasolabial Angle** | 90-98.5 degrees | 7.5 | Really Important |
| 8 | **Facial Convexity (Glabella)** | 168-176 degrees | 10 | Extremely Important |
| 9 | **Facial Convexity (Nasion)** | 167-175 degrees | 5 | Important |
| 10 | **Total Facial Convexity** | 137-147 degrees | 7.5 | Extremely Important |
| 11 | **Nasal Projection** | 0.5-0.7 | 5 | Really Important |
| 12 | **Nasomental Angle** | 125-132 degrees | 5 | Important |
| 13 | **Nasofacial Angle** | 30-37 degrees | 9 | Really Important |
| 14 | **Mentolabial Angle** | 108-117 degrees | 7.5 | Really Important |
| 15 | **Recession (Frankfurt Plane)** | None | 5 | Extremely Important |
| 16 | **Gonion to Mouth Line** | Below mouth | 6 | Important |
| 17 | **Rickets E-line** | Upper lip 4mm behind lower | 5 | Important |
| 18 | **Holdaway H-line** | Chin to upper lip | 5 | Important |
| 19 | **Steiner S-line** | Chin, lower/upper lip | 5 | Important |
| 20 | **Burstone Line** | Pogonion to subnasale | 5 | Important |
| 21 | **Submental Cervical Angle** | 92-100 degrees | 10 | Really Important |
| 22 | **Neck to Jaw Width** | 90-100% | 10 | Really Important |

---

## Detailed MISC Formula (Features Score)

Seven categories evaluated across 8 tiers (Tier 1 = best):

| Category | Max Points | Subcriteria |
|----------|------------|-------------|
| **Skin** | 160 | Clearness, hyperpigmentation, texture, scarring, wrinkles |
| **Eye Area** | 231 | Eyelids, sclera, lashes, brows, circles, color |
| **Coloring** | 135 | Skin tone, lip color, eye/hair/brow darkness |
| **Lower Third** | 170 | Gonions, chin shape/width, mandible features |
| **Lips** | 110 | Width, philtrum length, fullness, health |
| **Nose** | 110 | Alar width, bulbosity, tip definition, flare |
| **Other** | 115 | Ear positioning, facial symmetry |

**MISC Calculation:** `((Score + 460) / 1491) x 100`

---

## Detailed ANGU Formula (Angularity Score)

Nine features across 7 tiers measuring angular definition:

| Feature | Max Points |
|---------|------------|
| Mandible visibility | 24.75 |
| Facial 3D-ness | 18.75 |
| Gonion sharpness | 18.75 |
| Facial depth | 17.25 |
| Mandible/ramus visibility | 16.74 |
| Ogee curve | 15.75 |
| Cheekbone visibility | 15.11 |
| Chin angularity | 12.30 |
| Lower-midface fat | 10.43 |

**Range:** Max 149.83 / Min 19.03

---

## Detailed DIMO Formula (Dimorphism Score)

Eleven masculinity indicators across 5 tiers:

| Feature | Max Points |
|---------|------------|
| Eye depth | 22.32 |
| Brow ridge shape | 13.44 |
| Chin shape | 12.72 |
| Buccal fat size | 11.70 |
| Ramus length | 11.53 |
| Gonion outward growth | 11.04 |
| Upper third narrowing | 9.00 |
| Facial hair | 7.80 |
| Skin texture | 7.20 |
| Cheekbone size | 6.91 |
| Lip fullness | 6.34 |

**Range:** Max 120 / Min -67.44

---

## Detailed HARM Formula (Harmony Score)

Twenty-five proportional measurements across 7 tiers:

Major factors include:
- Jaw width
- Eye-brow distance
- Brow ridge angle
- Facial thirds (1:1:1 ratio)
- Nasofrontal angle (125-135 degrees)
- Neck width
- FWHR (1.8-2.0)
- Eye aspect ratio
- Gonial angle (~120 degrees)
- Ramus length
- Chin-philtrum ratio (~1:2)
- Lateral canthal tilt
- Bizygomatic width (140-150mm)
- Midface height (47-50mm)

**Range:** Max 389.74 / Min -409.92

---

## Overall Score Calculation

1. Normalize each component to 0-100 scale:
   `((Score - Min) / (Max - Min)) x 100`

2. Apply weighted percentages:
   - HARM x 0.32
   - MISC x 0.26
   - ANGU x 0.22
   - DIMO x 0.20

3. Calculate spread between highest and lowest component

4. Apply penalty: `Spread x 0.5`

5. **Final Score** = Weighted average - Penalty

The penalty mechanism prevents high scores in isolated categories from inflating overall ratings when other areas are deficient.

---

## Severity Classifications

### Point Deviation System

| Deviation | Impact | Classification |
|-----------|--------|----------------|
| Within ideal range | +Full points | Ideal |
| +/- 0.1 from FWHR ideal | -5 points | Minor deviation |
| Well outside range | -25 points (~5% total) | Major flaw |

### "Major Flaw" vs "Minor Flaw"

Based on forum discussions:

| Flaw Type | Definition | Examples |
|-----------|------------|----------|
| **Major Flaw** | Significantly impacts overall attractiveness, noticeable at first glance | Recessed chin, very high gonial angle (>130), submental fullness, severe asymmetry |
| **Minor Flaw** | Noticeable but doesn't significantly detract | Slightly long philtrum, minor asymmetry, slightly wide nose |

---

## Surgery Recommendations by Metric

### Lower Third Issues

| Problem | Metric Affected | Recommended Surgery |
|---------|-----------------|---------------------|
| Weak chin | Chin projection | Sliding genioplasty, chin implant |
| Rounded gonial angle | Gonial angle | Gonial angle implants, jaw angle augmentation |
| Recessed jaw | Facial convexity | BSSO, bimax surgery |
| Narrow jaw | Bigonial width | Wraparound jaw implants |
| Submental fullness | Submental angle | Submental liposuction, platysmaplasty |

### Midface Issues

| Problem | Metric Affected | Recommended Surgery |
|---------|-----------------|---------------------|
| Flat cheekbones | Cheekbone projection | Zygomatic implants, fillers |
| Sunken eyes | Infraorbital rim | Infraorbital rim implants |
| Long midface | Midface ratio | LeFort I with impaction |

### Eye Area Issues

| Problem | Metric Affected | Recommended Surgery |
|---------|-----------------|---------------------|
| Negative canthal tilt | Canthal tilt | Lateral canthoplasty |
| Upper eyelid excess | Eye area | Blepharoplasty |
| Hollow temples | Temple region | Temple fillers |

### Nose Issues

| Problem | Metric Affected | Recommended Surgery |
|---------|-----------------|---------------------|
| Wide nostrils | Nasal width ratio | Alar base reduction |
| Poor projection | Nasal projection | Rhinoplasty |

---

## Key Measurements Summary Table

| Measurement | Ideal (Males) | How to Measure |
|-------------|---------------|----------------|
| **FWHR** | 1.8-2.0 | Bizygomatic width / upper face height |
| **Midface Ratio** | 0.95-1.05 | IPD / nasion-to-upper-lip |
| **Gonial Angle** | 115-125 degrees | Mandible-ramus intersection |
| **Canthal Tilt** | 5-8 degrees | Medial to lateral canthus angle |
| **ESR** | 0.45-0.47 | IPD / bizygomatic width |
| **Eye Aspect Ratio** | 2.8-3.5 | Eye width / height |
| **Bigonial/Bizygomatic** | 88-95% | Jaw width / cheekbone width |
| **Chin-Philtrum** | 2.0-2.25 | Chin height / philtrum length |
| **Facial Thirds** | 33%/33%/34% | Upper/middle/lower face |
| **Submental Angle** | 92-100 degrees | Chin-to-neck angle |
| **Nasolabial Angle** | 90-105 degrees | Nose-to-upper-lip angle |
| **Total Facial Convexity** | 137-147 degrees | Overall profile projection |

---

## Sources

### Looksmax.org Threads
- [38 Most Important Facial Ratios](https://looksmax.org/threads/38-most-important-facial-ratios-and-the-ideal-measurements-high-effort.956143/)
- [Facial Harmony Ratios Guide](https://looksmax.org/threads/facial-harmony-ratios-guide.1742795/)
- [Complete Guide to PSL Ratings](https://looksmax.org/threads/complete-guide-to-psl-ratings.379179/)
- [2-10 Looks Scale Guide](https://looksmax.org/threads/a-2-10-looks-scale-and-a-structured-unbiased-guide-to-facial-analysis-rate-yourself-or-others-with-ease.1723949/)
- [Ideal Facial Ratios and Proportions](https://looksmax.org/threads/ideal-facial-ratios-and-proportions.57266/)
- [Surgeries and What They Do](https://looksmax.org/threads/surgeries-and-what-they-do.1167064/)
- [Complete Guide to Facial Ratios and Angles](https://looksmax.org/threads/the-complete-guide-to-facial-ratios-and-angles.1736927/)

### FaceIQ Services
- [FaceIQ Labs](https://www.faceiqlabs.com/)
- [FaceIQ Premium Analysis](https://faceiq.gumroad.com/l/full)
- [FaceIQ Basic Rating](https://faceiq.gumroad.com/l/basic)

### Additional Sources
- [QOVES Facial Analysis](https://www.qoves.com/)
- [PSL Scale Wiki](https://incels.wiki/w/PSL_rating)
- [Mewing Hub - FWHR Guide](https://mewinghub.com/blogs/looksmaxing-blog/fwhr-explained-measuring-calculating-and-improving-your-ratio)
- [Gonial Angle Looksmax Guide](https://mewinghub.com/blogs/looksmaxing-blog/gonial-angle-looksmax-transforming-your-jaw-aesthetics)

---

## Disclaimer

This document compiles information from online looksmaxxing communities and is NOT based on peer-reviewed scientific research. These measurements represent subjective aesthetic preferences discussed within these communities rather than clinically validated standards. FaceIQ Labs explicitly states their service is "for entertainment and informational purposes only" and should not be used for medical decisions.

| 3 | **Ramus to Mandible Ratio** | 0-0.7 | 10 | Really Important |
| 4 | **Nasofrontal Angle** | 106-130 degrees | 15 | Really Important |
| 5 | **Browridge Inclination** | 12-23 degrees | 4 | Important |
| 6 | **Nasal Tip Angle** | 103-113 degrees | 4 | Important |
| 7 | **Nasolabial Angle** | 90-98.5 degrees | 7.5 | Really Important |
| 8 | **Facial Convexity (Glabella)** | 168-176 degrees | 10 | Extremely Important |
| 9 | **Facial Convexity (Nasion)** | 167-175 degrees | 5 | Important |
| 10 | **Total Facial Convexity** | 137-147 degrees | 7.5 | Extremely Important |
| 11 | **Nasal Projection** | 0.5-0.7 | 5 | Really Important |
| 12 | **Nasomental Angle** | 125-132 degrees | 5 | Important |
| 13 | **Nasofacial Angle** | 30-37 degrees | 9 | Really Important |
| 14 | **Mentolabial Angle** | 108-117 degrees | 7.5 | Really Important |
| 15 | **Recession (Frankfurt Plane)** | None | 5 | Extremely Important |
| 16 | **Gonion to Mouth Line** | Below mouth | 6 | Important |
| 17 | **Rickets E-line** | Upper lip 4mm behind lower | 5 | Important |
| 18 | **Holdaway H-line** | Chin to upper lip | 5 | Important |
| 19 | **Steiner S-line** | Chin, lower/upper lip | 5 | Important |
| 20 | **Burstone Line** | Pogonion to subnasale | 5 | Important |
| 21 | **Submental Cervical Angle** | 92-100 degrees | 10 | Really Important |
| 22 | **Neck to Jaw Width** | 90-100% | 10 | Really Important |

---

## Detailed MISC Formula (Features Score)

Seven categories evaluated across 8 tiers (Tier 1 = best):

| Category | Max Points | Subcriteria |
|----------|------------|-------------|
| **Skin** | 160 | Clearness, hyperpigmentation, texture, scarring, wrinkles |
| **Eye Area** | 231 | Eyelids, sclera, lashes, brows, circles, color |
| **Coloring** | 135 | Skin tone, lip color, eye/hair/brow darkness |
| **Lower Third** | 170 | Gonions, chin shape/width, mandible features |
| **Lips** | 110 | Width, philtrum length, fullness, health |
| **Nose** | 110 | Alar width, bulbosity, tip definition, flare |
| **Other** | 115 | Ear positioning, facial symmetry |

**MISC Calculation:** `((Score + 460) / 1491) x 100`

---

## Detailed ANGU Formula (Angularity Score)

Nine features across 7 tiers measuring angular definition:

| Feature | Max Points |
|---------|------------|
| Mandible visibility | 24.75 |
| Facial 3D-ness | 18.75 |
| Gonion sharpness | 18.75 |
| Facial depth | 17.25 |
| Mandible/ramus visibility | 16.74 |
| Ogee curve | 15.75 |
| Cheekbone visibility | 15.11 |
| Chin angularity | 12.30 |
| Lower-midface fat | 10.43 |

**Range:** Max 149.83 / Min 19.03

---

## Detailed DIMO Formula (Dimorphism Score)

Eleven masculinity indicators across 5 tiers:

| Feature | Max Points |
|---------|------------|
| Eye depth | 22.32 |
| Brow ridge shape | 13.44 |
| Chin shape | 12.72 |
| Buccal fat size | 11.70 |
| Ramus length | 11.53 |
| Gonion outward growth | 11.04 |
| Upper third narrowing | 9.00 |
| Facial hair | 7.80 |
| Skin texture | 7.20 |
| Cheekbone size | 6.91 |
| Lip fullness | 6.34 |

**Range:** Max 120 / Min -67.44

---

## Detailed HARM Formula (Harmony Score)

Twenty-five proportional measurements across 7 tiers:

Major factors include:
- Jaw width
- Eye-brow distance
- Brow ridge angle
- Facial thirds (1:1:1 ratio)
- Nasofrontal angle (125-135 degrees)
- Neck width
- FWHR (1.8-2.0)
- Eye aspect ratio
- Gonial angle (~120 degrees)
- Ramus length
- Chin-philtrum ratio (~1:2)
- Lateral canthal tilt
- Bizygomatic width (140-150mm)
- Midface height (47-50mm)

**Range:** Max 389.74 / Min -409.92

---

## Overall Score Calculation

1. Normalize each component to 0-100 scale:
   `((Score - Min) / (Max - Min)) x 100`

2. Apply weighted percentages:
   - HARM x 0.32
   - MISC x 0.26
   - ANGU x 0.22
   - DIMO x 0.20

3. Calculate spread between highest and lowest component

4. Apply penalty: `Spread x 0.5`

5. **Final Score** = Weighted average - Penalty

The penalty mechanism prevents high scores in isolated categories from inflating overall ratings when other areas are deficient.

---

## Severity Classifications

### Point Deviation System

| Deviation | Impact | Classification |
|-----------|--------|----------------|
| Within ideal range | +Full points | Ideal |
| +/- 0.1 from FWHR ideal | -5 points | Minor deviation |
| Well outside range | -25 points (~5% total) | Major flaw |

### "Major Flaw" vs "Minor Flaw"

Based on forum discussions:

| Flaw Type | Definition | Examples |
|-----------|------------|----------|
| **Major Flaw** | Significantly impacts overall attractiveness, noticeable at first glance | Recessed chin, very high gonial angle (>130), submental fullness, severe asymmetry |
| **Minor Flaw** | Noticeable but doesn't significantly detract | Slightly long philtrum, minor asymmetry, slightly wide nose |

---

## Surgery Recommendations by Metric

### Lower Third Issues

| Problem | Metric Affected | Recommended Surgery |
|---------|-----------------|---------------------|
| Weak chin | Chin projection | Sliding genioplasty, chin implant |
| Rounded gonial angle | Gonial angle | Gonial angle implants, jaw angle augmentation |
| Recessed jaw | Facial convexity | BSSO, bimax surgery |
| Narrow jaw | Bigonial width | Wraparound jaw implants |
| Submental fullness | Submental angle | Submental liposuction, platysmaplasty |

### Midface Issues

| Problem | Metric Affected | Recommended Surgery |
|---------|-----------------|---------------------|
| Flat cheekbones | Cheekbone projection | Zygomatic implants, fillers |
| Sunken eyes | Infraorbital rim | Infraorbital rim implants |
| Long midface | Midface ratio | LeFort I with impaction |

### Eye Area Issues

| Problem | Metric Affected | Recommended Surgery |
|---------|-----------------|---------------------|
| Negative canthal tilt | Canthal tilt | Lateral canthoplasty |
| Upper eyelid excess | Eye area | Blepharoplasty |
| Hollow temples | Temple region | Temple fillers |

### Nose Issues

| Problem | Metric Affected | Recommended Surgery |
|---------|-----------------|---------------------|
| Wide nostrils | Nasal width ratio | Alar base reduction |
| Poor projection | Nasal projection | Rhinoplasty |

---

## Key Measurements Summary Table

| Measurement | Ideal (Males) | How to Measure |
|-------------|---------------|----------------|
| **FWHR** | 1.8-2.0 | Bizygomatic width / upper face height |
| **Midface Ratio** | 0.95-1.05 | IPD / nasion-to-upper-lip |
| **Gonial Angle** | 115-125 degrees | Mandible-ramus intersection |
| **Canthal Tilt** | 5-8 degrees | Medial to lateral canthus angle |
| **ESR** | 0.45-0.47 | IPD / bizygomatic width |
| **Eye Aspect Ratio** | 2.8-3.5 | Eye width / height |
| **Bigonial/Bizygomatic** | 88-95% | Jaw width / cheekbone width |
| **Chin-Philtrum** | 2.0-2.25 | Chin height / philtrum length |
| **Facial Thirds** | 33%/33%/34% | Upper/middle/lower face |
| **Submental Angle** | 92-100 degrees | Chin-to-neck angle |
| **Nasolabial Angle** | 90-105 degrees | Nose-to-upper-lip angle |
| **Total Facial Convexity** | 137-147 degrees | Overall profile projection |

---

## Sources

### Looksmax.org Threads
- [38 Most Important Facial Ratios](https://looksmax.org/threads/38-most-important-facial-ratios-and-the-ideal-measurements-high-effort.956143/)
- [Facial Harmony Ratios Guide](https://looksmax.org/threads/facial-harmony-ratios-guide.1742795/)
- [Complete Guide to PSL Ratings](https://looksmax.org/threads/complete-guide-to-psl-ratings.379179/)
- [2-10 Looks Scale Guide](https://looksmax.org/threads/a-2-10-looks-scale-and-a-structured-unbiased-guide-to-facial-analysis-rate-yourself-or-others-with-ease.1723949/)
- [Ideal Facial Ratios and Proportions](https://looksmax.org/threads/ideal-facial-ratios-and-proportions.57266/)
- [Surgeries and What They Do](https://looksmax.org/threads/surgeries-and-what-they-do.1167064/)
- [Complete Guide to Facial Ratios and Angles](https://looksmax.org/threads/the-complete-guide-to-facial-ratios-and-angles.1736927/)

### FaceIQ Services
- [FaceIQ Labs](https://www.faceiqlabs.com/)
- [FaceIQ Premium Analysis](https://faceiq.gumroad.com/l/full)
- [FaceIQ Basic Rating](https://faceiq.gumroad.com/l/basic)

### Additional Sources
- [QOVES Facial Analysis](https://www.qoves.com/)

- [Mewing Hub - FWHR Guide](https://mewinghub.com/blogs/looksmaxing-blog/fwhr-explained-measuring-calculating-and-improving-your-ratio)
- [Gonial Angle Looksmax Guide](https://mewinghub.com/blogs/looksmaxing-blog/gonial-angle-looksmax-transforming-your-jaw-aesthetics)

---

## Disclaimer

This document compiles information from online looksmaxxing communities and is NOT based on peer-reviewed scientific research. These measurements represent subjective aesthetic preferences discussed within these communities rather than clinically validated standards. FaceIQ Labs explicitly states their service is "for entertainment and informational purposes only" and should not be used for medical decisions.
